triples.name: Lean (proof assistant)
triples.relevance: The paper formalizes arbitration games in Lean4, using it as the tool for mechanizing fraud proof game strategies.

triples.name: Formal verification
triples.relevance: The paper proposes machine-checkable formal verification strategies for arbitration games in blockchain systems.

triples.name: Game theory
triples.relevance: Arbitration games are formalized as game-theoretic models where two players have strategic interactions in fraud proof disputes.

triples.name: Blockchain
triples.relevance: The paper addresses layer 2 blockchain architectures that use fraud proofs for secure computation validation.

triples.name: Bitcoin scalability problem
triples.relevance: Layer 2 optimistic rollups are presented as a solution to the blockchain scalability problem.

triples.name: Ethereum
triples.relevance: Optimistic rollups are primarily deployed on Ethereum as Layer 2 solutions for improving scalability.

triples.name: Binary tree
triples.relevance: Arbitration games are formalized on finite binary trees for asserting data-availability and membership.

triples.name: Cryptographic hash function
triples.relevance: Hashes are posted as compact witnesses of knowledge in disputable assertions to enable efficient fraud proof construction.

triples.name: Dispute resolution
triples.relevance: Arbitration games implement a formal dispute resolution process between two opposing players to determine computation validity.

triples.name: Mathematical proof
triples.relevance: The paper develops machine-checkable mathematical proofs of winning strategies for honest players in arbitration games.
